boldPPP.title: Nigeria Signals Bold PPP Future at 2025 Infrastructure Summit
boldPPP.subtitle: Private capital is key to unlocking Nigeria's trillion-naira infrastructure ambitions — and SEAP is ready to lead from the front.
boldPPP.sec1title: Abuja Hosts Global Infrastructure Leaders at Landmark PPP Summit
boldPPP.sec1text: Nigeria reaffirmed its commitment to Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs) as the foundation of national infrastructure delivery during the 2025 PPP Summit, held June 17-18 in Abuja. Organized by the Infrastructure Concession Regulatory Commission (ICRC), the summit gathered key decision-makers, international financiers, and innovators to accelerate infrastructure deployment — particularly in power, transportation, digital economy, and energy access.
boldPPP.personqoute: We are no longer talking about vision. We are implementing
boldPPP.sec1text2: resident Tinubu emphasized the $2.3 trillion infrastructure gap that Nigeria faces and called for an enabling environment that attracts global private capital. Also in attendance were senior leaders from Afreximbank, IFC, AfDB, and the Nigerian Sovereign Investment Authority (NSIA).

bullets1.value: Many discussions centered on transitioning infrastructure plans into investment-ready pipelines — echoing SEAP's hybrid energy and clean cooking frameworks already underway in 774 LGAs.
Global players emphasized capacity building and knowledge-sharing, aligning with SEAP's partnership model (CKCEP, DAS, ALGON).
The ICRC introduced a new platform to track private capital in PPP projects. SEAP is exploring integration into this national registry to improve investor confidence.

boldPPP.blogqoute: Nigeria is no longer the future — it's the present for infrastructure scale
boldPPP.sec3title: This summit positions SEAP perfectly to

sec3numbered.text: Engage development finance institutions (DFIs) for clean energy infrastructure
Showcase shovel-ready PPP-aligned projects in e-mobility, LPG distribution, and off-grid solar
Build credibility within national PPP frameworks, particularly under the ICRC and Ministry of Finance's capital mapping efforts

miniGrids.title: Nigeria Joins Forces with WeLight to Power Rural Communities with $200M Mini-Grids
miniGrids.subtitle: A new PPP marks a major leap in delivering reliable, renewable energy to 1.5-2 million Nigerians.
miniGrids.sec1title: Reliable Power for Rural Nigerians at Scale
miniGrids.sec1text: In a landmark collaboration, the Rural Electrification Agency (REA) signed a $200 million Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with WeLight, a pan-African distributed renewable energy firm, on March 10, 2025, to deploy 400 mini-grids and 50 larger MetroGrids across Nigeria's underserved rural and peri-urban regions
miniGrids.personqoute: This MOU not only represents a leap toward providing clean electricity to millions in Nigeria but also supports WeLight's ambition to become a truly pan-African company,
miniGrids.sec1text2: Backed by critical support from the World Bank and African Development Bank (AfDB), the project aligns with Nigeria's ambition to raise renewables from 22% to 50% of its energy mix, delivering clean and consistent power to an estimated 1.52 million residents

bullets1.value: Instantly expands access in locations formerly too remote for grid extension.
Enables businesses and critical services—schools, clinics, cold storage—to function predictably.
Aligns with SEAP's PPP-aligned models for hybrid power, smart cooking, and e-mobility solutions.

miniGrids.blogqoute: This is a pivotal step in Nigeria's energy transition, demonstrating that clean, renewable infrastructure can scale with private capital.

sec3numbered.text: Developer Integration - SEAP is evaluating how its hybrid mini-grid and clean cooking offerings can build on these PPP frameworks
Financier Alignment - Invitations are out to DFIs and impact investors to co-finance rollouts anchored in SEAP's proven project templates.
Webinar Invite - Join our session on July 2, 2025, to explore how PPP infrastructure platforms like this open avenues in energy, agri, and mobility for SEAP stakeholders.

afdbMobilizes.title: AfDB Mobilizes $2.2B to Spark Nigeria's Agro-Processing Boom
afdbMobilizes.subtitle: Huge investment to reduce food imports and bring processing capabilities closer to farmers in 28 states.
afdbMobilizes.sec1title: A Game-Changing Push for Agro-Industrial Zones
afdbMobilizes.sec1text: On April 8, 2025, the African Development Bank (AfDB) announced plans to mobilize $2.2billion in support of agro-processing zones across 28 Nigerian states, following the successful first-phase pilot in Kaduna State — which was backed by over $500million raised in 2022
afdbMobilizes.personqoute: We have been able, I would like to say, to mobilize $2.2billion of investment interest to support the second phase across Nigeria,
afdbMobilizes.sec1text2: This bold move aims at boosting food security and employment by placing crop-processing facilities near farming communities, cutting post-harvest loss, and fortifying value chains. Nigeria spent $4.7billion on food imports in 2024, a trend this initiative aims to reverse
afdbMobilizes.bullets1title: Why It Matters for Nigeria—and SEAP

bullets1.value: Aligns with SEAP's efforts in agribusiness hubs, solar-powered processing, and cold-chain infrastructure.
Zones located in rural and peri-urban LGAs echo SEAP's deployment areas for hybrid energy and clean cooking.

bullets1.key: Financing Models: Multi-stakeholder backing—including Arab Bank for Economic Development, Afreximbank, Sahara Farms fintech, and French/U.S. institutions
bullets1.value: mirrors SEAP's blended finance approach between DFIs, private equity, and local developers

afdbMobilizes.blogqoute: Agro-processing zones aim to create facilities to process agricultural produce closer to farmers, reducing post-harvest losses and strengthening value chains.

sec3numbered.text: Integrate hybrid energy systems into processing zones to ensure reliable, cost-effective operations.
Align investment frameworks with agro-industrial PPPs backed by DFIs and development partners.
Host a Virtual Roundtable on August 15, 2025, to explore PPP structures, tech integration, and co-investment models in agro-processing.

chinaNews.title: China, Nigeria, and Others Reaffirm Global Cooperation on Climate Action
chinaNews.subtitle: China hosts global seminar on climate adaptation and energy transition with Nigeria and six nations pledging deeper cooperation on clean energy and capacity building
chinaNews.sec1title: A Global Commitment to Green Growth
chinaNews.sec1text:
A major milestone in global climate dialogue unfolded as the International Seminar on Climate Change Adaptation and Energy Transition concluded in Hangzhou, China, with renewed calls for international cooperation, knowledge-sharing, and green innovation. The two-week programme brought together 25 officials and experts from seven Belt and Road countries, including Nigeria, Chile, Cuba, Grenada, Indonesia, Tunisia, and Uzbekistan.
Hosted by the Hangzhou Regional Center (Asia-Pacific) for Small Hydro Power (HRC) and sponsored by China's Ministry of Commerce, the seminar served as a powerful platform to explore clean energy innovation, low-carbon policy, and real-world technologies driving energy access in developing nations.
chinaNews.personqoute: We embarked on a fulfilling and productive journey together,
chinaNews.person: Mr. Xu Zhifeng, Director General, HRC
chinaNews.bullets2title: Through in-depth lectures, live case studies, and expert visits, participants studied
chinaNews.bullets2text: Study tours included the Laoshikan and Fushi Hydropower Stations, showcasing China's green construction achievements, and visits to the NARI Group Corporation for a first-hand look at next-gen renewable energy systems and hydraulic simulations.
